संकेतशब्द* वापरकर्तानाव* Login User Name Forgot Password New User Registration Submit Age Address line 1 First name * Middle name Last name * Date of Birth Address line 2 "Pin code *" Village/City * "District * " State Mobile number* Email Education "Designation " "Role " 1. आपल्याकडे अंतरासाठी अस्पष्ट दृष्टी आहे? जर हो तर कोणत्या डोळ्यात? होय नाही २. आपल्याला वर्तमानपत्रात किंवा जवळील कामाच्या दरम्यान सामान्य प्रिंट वाचण्यात अडचण आहे? जर हो तर कोणत्या डोळ्यात? 3.आपल्याकडे लालसरपणा, वेदना, अश्रू, स्त्राव किंवा अस्वस्थ डोळे आहेत? होय - लालसरपणा / वेदना / फाडणे / डिस्चार्ज / अस्वस्थ डोळे 4. तुमच्या डोळ्यात इतर काही अडचणी आहेत का? डोळ्यासमोर काळे डाग डोळ्यावर वाढ पापणीवर सूज येणे खाज सुटणे / चिडचिड होणे डोळ्यावरील ताण डोकेदुखी हलकी संवेदनशीलता चमक झाकणाच्या फरकावर पांढरे तराजू डोळे विचलन परदेशी शरीर संवेदना कोरडेपणा प्रकाश सुमारे रंगीत हलो चकाकी दुहेरी दृष्टी शून्य 5.तुम्हाला दोन्ही डोळ्यांमध्ये अडचण आहे? नाही तर कोणत्या डोळ्यात अडचण आहे? उजवा डोळा डावा डोळा दोन्ही डोळा प्रस्तुत करणे "6.समस्या कधी सुरू झाल्या? " 7.लक्षणांची सुरूवात कशी होती? ते अचानक होते किंवा हळूहळू होते? क्रमिक अचानक 8. उपरोक्त लक्षणे आपण किती वेळा अनुभवता? कधीकधी वारंवार सतत 5.आपण दूर किंवा जवळ जवळ चष्मा घातला आहे? जर होय तर आपल्याला आपल्या चष्मासह स्पष्टपणे पाहण्यात अडचण आहे? होय, चष्मासह अडचण आहे होय, चष्मा घेण्यास अडचण नाही चष्मा घातलेला नाही 6. डोळ्याच्या शस्त्रक्रिया, डोळ्याच्या दुखापती किंवा डोळ्यांच्या उपचारांचा आपला पूर्वीचा इतिहास आहे का? मोतीबिंदू शस्त्रक्रिया रेटिनल शस्त्रक्रिया काचबिंदू उपचार डोळ्याच्या दुखापती इतर लेझर उपचार 7. आपण प्रणालीगत आजारासाठी औषधे घेत आहात? मधुमेह उच्च रक्तदाब दमा थायरॉईड जप्ती Lerलर्जी संधिवात इतर शून्य 8. तुमच्या पहिल्या पदवीच्या नातेवाईकांपैकी कोणास ऑक्टुलर समस्या आहे? (वडील / आई / भावंड / काकू / काका) होय नाही पुढे 1.Distance vision without glasses Right Eye Left eye Less than 3/60 Less than 6/60, more than 3/60 More than 6/60, less than 6/18 More than 6/18 2. Distance vision with glasses 3. Near vision without glasses Cannot see N6 Can see N6 4. Near vision with glasses 5. Category of visual impairment Mild visual impairment Moderate visual impairment Severe visual impairment Blindness Near vision impairment HISTORY TAKING QUESTIONNAIRE VISION SCREENING Sphere Cylinder < 1.00D >1.00D Axis range TORCHLIGHT EXAMINATION Present Absent "Cataract is commonly seen in people above 40 years." "Children may also develop the cataract." "People with diabetes or those taking high doses of steroid medications are also at high risk "
What are the symptoms of the cataract? "●	Blurring of vision. " "If left untreated, the patient may turn blind gradually. " "Other possible symptoms are the presence of bright circles around the light, glare, difficulty in the night driving, light seem too dim for reading. "
"What is the treatment for Cataract ? " "The only treatment for cataract is surgery. " "In early stages vision may improve with glasses." "In cataract surgery, eye surgeons will remove the cloudy lens and place an artificial lens in the exact position of the original lens. " "Cataract surgeries are simple, quick, painless, and suture less procedures. " "The patient can go for surgery when cataract starts affecting their lifestyle. "
"Myopia or Near-sightedness- In myopia, there will be difficulty in seeing distant objects. Myopia is usually inherited. " "Hyperopia or Long Sightedness- In hyperopia there will be difficulty in seeing near objects. " "Astigmatism results in distorted vision due to an irregularly curved cornea. (the clear structure covering the eyeball). " "Presbyopia is linked to aging and can result in blurring of near vision "
What are the symptoms? "Blurring of vision. " "Headache /watering/eye-strain while doing near work/studying/watching TV . " "Children find difficulty in reading from the blackboard when sitting in the backbenches. " "Children tend to watch TV from a close distance. " "Squeezing/frequent blinking of the eyes while watching the distant objects. "
What are the symptoms of presbyopia? "Difficulty in reading, doing computer work, or reading numbers on the mobile phone." "Difficulty in threading the needle/stitching. " "Difficulty in cleaning pulses/rice etc. "
What is the available treatment? "The need for refractive error correction depends on the patient's symptoms, age, and visual needs." "Asymptomatic patients with low refractive errors may not require correction, " "Correction options include spectacles, contact lenses, or surgery. "
"Glaucoma causes loss of vision by damaging the part of the eye called the optic nerve. " "Optic nerves carry information from your eyes to the brain. "
"Glaucoma occurs due to build-up of fluid within the front chamber of the eye (anterior chamber) " "This increases pressure inside the eye, causing damage to the optic nerve. "
"People with glaucoma usually do not show any symptoms initially. " "As glaucoma worsens side vision will get reduced and eventually central vision will also get affected. " "Patients may experience headaches and pain in the eye, the coloured halo around light, nausea, frequent change of spectacle. "
"Anyone can get glaucoma, but some people have higher chances of getting glaucoma. 
●	People above 40 years 
●	Family history of glaucoma 
●	Near-sightedness 
●	Diabetes and hypertension 
●	Long term steroid use " "There is no permanent cure for glaucoma . " "Glaucoma can be prevented from getting worse by medication or surgery. " "Identifying it early is key to protecting your vision. "
It is an eye condition commonly seen in people 50 years and above. It damages central vision and causes difficulty in reading and driving
"●	Age 50 years and above 

●	Cigarette smoking 

●	Family history of AMD 

●	High cholesterol 

●	Heart disease 

●	Overweight 

●	High blood pressure " How is it treated? Currently, no treatment exists for early ARMD Advise patients to get a comprehensive eye check-up at least once a year and to maintain a healthy lifestyle. For late cases, high-dose vitamins and minerals are advised
The retina is the tissue layer located in the back of your eye. Prolonged increase in blood pressure can cause damage to your retina. When your blood pressure is too high, the retina’s blood vessel walls may thicken.
This may cause your blood vessels to become narrow, which then restricts blood from reaching the retina. Over time, high blood pressure can cause damage to the retina’s blood vessels, limit the retina’s function, and put pressure on the optic nerve, causing vision problems. This condition is called hypertensive retinopathy.
Symptoms usually do not develop until late in the disease and include blurred vision. It can be diagnosed by through a detailed examination of your retina. Also hypertension combined with diabetes greatly increases the risk of visual loss.
Hypertensive retinopathy is managed primarily by controlling hypertension. Sometimes laser or injection of corticosteroids is used
Diabetes is a condition in which glucose level in the blood is higher than normal. A hormone called insulin in your body helps cells to take glucose for energy. In diabetes, the body will be either unable to produce sufficient insulin or may be unable to utilize insulin well. This causes glucose to stay in the blood and causes damage
Diabetes can result in diabetic retinopathy. In diabetic retinopathy, small blood vessels leak and bleed the retina and can cause blindness
What are the symptoms of diabetes? "You will usually not experience symptoms in the early stages. 

●	A sudden increase in black spots 

●	Blurred vision 

●	Sudden loss of vision in one eye 

●	Bright circles around light 

●	Flashing light " How can you diagnose diabetic retinopathy? All people with diabetes must get dilated eye exams at regular intervals to find out the development of any signs of retinopathy, even if their blood sugar is under control. Is diabetic retinopathy treatable? In the early stages of diabetic retinopathy control of blood glucose level and an annual or more often dilated eye examination are recommended. In late stages, treatment options include - medication, lasers, and surgery " How to control blood sugar levels? Regular exercise, following a healthy meal plan "●	Constant eye rubbing 
●	Extreme sensitivity to light 
●	Chronic redness 
●	Chronic watering from eyes 
●	Poor focusing 
●	White instead of a black pupil 
●	Trouble in following objects with eyes 
●	Abnormal alignment of eyes " "a.	Refractive error 
b.	Corneal scarring mainly from Vitamin A deficiency and measles 
c.	Cataract 
d.	Retinopathy of prematurity 
e.	Refractive error (mostly myopia) 
f. 	Low vision. " Refractive error occurs when the eyes fail to focus light coming from the object. Myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism are the type of refractive error seen in young children. Symptoms of refractive error can include blurry vision, difficulty seeing up close, squinting, and headaches In amblyopia vision in one of the eyes is reduced because the eye and the brain are not working together properly. It failed to correct the refractive error in children, it results in amblyopia or lazy eye "Cataracts are a cloudiness that occurs in the lens of the eye " In children, abnormal lens development during pregnancy may result in congenital cataracts. Genetic disorders, infections, and trauma can cause cataracts. Common symptoms are the presence of white or yellow “glow” in the pupil in flash photos, lack of reaction to light, rapid eye movement, reduced vision "If the congenital cataract is not treated timely, it can hinder normal vision development and cause amblyopia " Congenital cataracts are typically treated by cataract surgery. The cloudy lens is removed and is replaced either by an artificial lens, or the using contact lenses Retinopathy of prematurity affects children born prematurely. Mild forms of retinopathy of prematurely usually resolve by itself but severe forms can result in blindness, if not treated Screening of premature babies for retinopathy of prematurity and timely treatment is very important. Severe cases of ROP may require surgical treatments. Preterm children, and those who develop hypoxia, infection, or breathlessness after birth need to be examined within 30 days of birth. "Squints usually develop during early childhood. " The eyes of the child will be abnormally aligned. The eye appears to cross or one wanders to one side. "Squint is best corrected if noticed during early childhood " If the squint is not corrected, the brain will ignore the weaker eye Yes No "Normal " "Diffuse swelling " "White scales on the lid margin " "Stye / chalazion " Abnormal closure "Lashes facing inward " "Crusting " White with few veins "Red " Whitish mass present "Others " "Black and shiny " "White or grey areas " "Foreign body " "Black "
"●	Redness 
●	Eye pain 
●	Sensitivity to light 
●	Blurring of vision 
●	Watering " "a.	Ocular injuries 
b.	Corneal ulceration 
c.	Trachoma 
d.	Vitamin A deficiency " Chemical burns and splashes into the eye Getting sand, dust or other foreign bodies in your eyes Getting scratches on the eye Don’t let children play dangerous games like Gulli-danda, bows, and arrows. Always use proper personal protective equipment recommended at work. Items of daily use like sharp edged toys, knives, needles, scissors, etc., should be kept away from children. Avoid the use of chemicals while playing Holi. Don’t stand too close to firecrackers, adult supervision is essential, while children are playing with crackers. Wash your eyes immediately in case of the chemical splash of something fell in your eyes Go to an eye doctor or casuality immediately Avoid rubbing of your eyes A corneal ulcer is an open sore present on the cornea. If left untreated can result in corneal blindness "●	Redness and pain 
●	Foreign body sensation in your eyes 
●	Watering of eyes 
●	Sensitivity to light 
●	Blurring of vision " It is commonly caused by infections (bacterial, viral, parasitic, fungal), injury to the cornea, dry eye Most of the causes of corneal ulceration are preventable. Contact lens wearers People with corneal injuries or burn people who use steroid eye drops people with eyelid disorders that prevent proper functioning of the eyelid Don't let your children play with sharp objects, firecrackers, etc. "Always use correct protective eyewear at work " If you are contact lens wearer safe handling, cleaning and storage of contact lens is important Trachoma is one of the preventable causes of blindness. It is an infectious disease affecting your cornea and conjunctiva. The infection spreads through personal contact (via hands, clothes or bedding) and by flies that have been in contact with discharge from the eyes or nose of an infected person. permanent damage to the cornea Pain and discomfort Turning inward of eyelashes "Wash your eyes and face several times with clean water. " Keep your towel and handkerchief separate from others. Do not let house flies breed both within the house and in the surrounding. Maintain personal hygiene and environmental cleanliness. Treatment of trachoma is possible. Put the eye ointment given by your doctor. Wash your eyes several times with clean water. Inturned eyelashes can be surgically corrected Vitamin ‘A’ is an essential nutrient for the eyes. Deficiency of vitamin A occurs due to: "●	Deficiency of Vitamin A in the diet. 
●	Several episodes of diarrhoea. 
●	Measles and other diseases " If left untreated, it results in total blindness in children. The condition is curable at an early stage. Poor vision in dim light and at night. The white portion of the eye appears lustreless and dull. The Infant’s skin and eyes appear dry and wrinkled. Include vitamin A rich food in your diet (green leafy vegetables, carrot, yellow fruits like papaya, mango, banana, and dairy products- milk, curd, cottage cheese. The non-vegetarian sources are fish, egg, and meat.) All infants should be breastfed from the very first day of their birth. Vitamin A prophylaxis should be given to all the children from 9 months to 5 years of age at an interval of 6 months. Open Close
Wash and sanitize your hands frequently. Clean your eyes daily with water to get free of infections. Don’t touch your eyes with unclean hands. If it is necessary to itch or rub eyes use a tissue instead of fingers. Keep your personalized articles like towel, handkerchief, bed linen, etc. separate to prevent transmission of infected eye conditions. Avoid instilling any substance like ghee, cow milk, Gulab Jal, honey, and homemade remedies in the eyes. Only use medications prescribed by your doctor. Discard the eye drops once opened within one month of opening, even if their expiry date is not reached. Always read in good light conditions, dim light strains the eyes. Do not see a solar eclipse with naked eyes as it may harm your eyes. Keep your premises clean.
Avoid smoking. Maintain a balanced diet. Exercise regularly. Include vitamin A rich food in your diet (green leafy vegetables, carrot, yellow fruits like papaya, mango, banana, and dairy products- milk, curd, cottage cheese. The non-vegetarian sources are fish, egg, and meat.)
Always wear or remove your glasses with two hands, this can prevent bending the frame. Always put your spectacles back in the case after the use. Never leave your glasses lens-side down on a table. Do not use dirty and scratched glasses. Do not share or use others spectacles. Clean your glasses every day with a soft piece of cloth.
Tilt your head back. Pull your lower eyelid down to create a “cup” that holds the drops or ointment. Put in the prescribed amount of medicine and close your eyes to distribute it evenly. If you have trouble doing this, ask a friend or relative for help. Start with a fresh bottle of medicine after surgery so germs don’t get transferred.
Instil eye-drops/ointments as advised by your operating surgeon. Protect eyes from bright sunlight, dust, smoke Avoid lifting heavyweights. Wear goggles. Before cleaning eyes, wash hands with soap and water. Clean your eyes with clean cotton soaked in boiling water for 10 minutes after cooling Start wiping from the inner corner and move to the periphery. Do not press or rub it. If redness, pain, or sudden loss of vision is observed, the patient should contact the doctor immediately. Get follow up check-up after one week of the surgery and again after 4-6 weeks for spectacles requirement. Don’t get soap, shampoo, or other irritants in your eye. Do wear eye shields at night to protect your eyes during sleep. Don’t bend over to pick things up; kneel instead.
Hygiene and Eye care
Wash your hands with mild soap and dry your hands using lint-free cloth before handling contact lenses Avoid the use of oily soaps, lotions or oily cosmetics and hand sanitizer before handling contact lens Ensure that your lens is moist, clean, clear and free of any nicks or tears before putting in eyes Remove your lenses immediately and contact your eye care personnel, if you experience eye discomfort, excessive tearing, vision changes, and redness of the eye or other problems Never wear your lenses beyond the prescribed wear schedule, as serious complications may occur, including loss of vision. Always store your lens in a clean case and replace it once in a month. Bacteria can grow in dirty contact lens cases.
Keep your computer screen lower to your eye level Position computer to avoid glare from overhead lamps, windows Use drapes and curtains Switch off excessive light in the room Adjust the display setting of your computer Blink your eyes frequents Take frequent breaks Start using the 20-20-20 rule to reduce eye fatigue. Every 20 minutes, look away from your screen and fix your eyes on something at least 20 feet away for at least 20 seconds. Computer-related eye care problems can be solved to an extent by making changes in the positioning of your computer, by proper eye care and taking regular breaks. Vision is one among the five senses and eyes are the window through which we can see the world. Often we ignore the importance of the eye and act lazy in taking care of our eyes. Eyes are situated within a bony socket in the skull. The eye consists of the following parts Eyelids can be described as a curtain of tissue placed in front of the eyes. Upper and lower eyelids together with eyelashes protect our eyes from sunlight, dust falling in our eyes, and from ocular injuries. The white portion of the eye that is seen on the outer surface is called the sclera. Sclera protects the inner part of our eyes. The cornea is the transparent structure placed centrally in front of our eyes. Light enters our eyes through the cornea. Iris is the circular band located behind the cornea. The color of the iris can vary from black, brown, or blue. The function of the iris is similar to the diaphragm of a camera. It controls the amount of light reaching to the back of the eye i.e. retina. The pupil is the small aperture seen in the middle of iris. The light passes through pupil to reach the retina The lens is the transparent structure placed inside the eye. It helps in focusing of light on the retina The retina is the place where all the light entering the eye falls and forms the image of the object. The retina is the innermost layer of the layer located at the back of the eye The optic nerve carries the image formed by retina towards the brain, where the image is processed The working of the human eye is similar to that of a camera. Light enters the eye through the eye aperture called pupil and travels through the lens and forms an image on the retina. The image formed on the retina is carried towards the brain through the optic nerve. Defects in any of these structures can result in the dimension of vision and can even result in blindness. ≥ 6/12 The people who are having a range/Yellow/White Ration Card and Antyodaya and Annapurna Ration card.> List of valid Photo Id proofs to be accepted along with document of eligible criteria:

Cataract What is a cataract ? A cataract is the clouding of the transparent lens of the eye. The cataract blocks the passage of light through the lens and can cause a reduction of vision. Who is at the risk of developing cataract? Refractive error and low vision What is refractive error ? Refractive error occurs when the eyes fail to focus the images of the objects in the outside world. Which are types of refractive error? Glaucoma What is glaucoma ? What are the risk factors ? What is hypertensive retinopathy ? What are its symptoms ? How is it treated? What is diabetes ? How does diabetes affect eyes ?
